questions.text: Which of the following macroscopic features is most characteristic of Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Continuous inflammation from the rectum extending proximally

options.label: B
options.text: Erythematous, granular mucosa with superficial ulcerations

options.label: C
options.text: Deep, punched-out ulcers with transmural inflammation

options.label: D
options.text: Thickened bowel wall and mesenteric fat wrapping

questions.correct_answer: D. Thickened bowel wall and mesenteric fat wrapping
questions.explanation:
Feature

Ulcerative Colitis

Crohn's Disease

Location

Rectum and colon, continuous; does not involve small intestine.

Any part of the GI tract; often the terminal ileum, colon; can involve small bowel and upper GI tract.

Extent

Continuous inflammation; no skip lesions.

Patchy inflammation with skip lesions between affected areas.

Appearance

Erythematous, granular mucosa; superficial ulcers.

Deep, serpiginous ulcers, especially on the mesenteric side.

Wall Involvement

Mucosa and submucosa only.

Transmural inflammation through all bowel layers.

Strictures

Rare.

Common due to transmural inflammation and fibrosis.

Fistulas

Rare, usually perianal.

Common, including between bowel loops and adjacent organs.

Fat Wrapping

Absent.

Present; "creeping fat" around the bowel wall.

Additional Features

-

Thickened bowel wall; thickened mesentery with enlarged lymph nodes.

Images

Feature

Ulcerative Colitis

Crohn's Disease

Inflammation

Limited to mucosa and submucosa.
  • Transmural, affecting all bowel wall layers.
  • Transmural Lymphoid Aggregates

Inflammatory Cells

Predominantly polymorphonuclear leukocytes in lamina propria.

Chronic inflammation with mononuclear cells, edema, hyperemia, and lymphangiectasia.

Crypt Abscesses

May be present, but not unique.

Can be present.

Goblet Cells

Mucin depletion may occur.

Not specifically noted.

Granulomas

Absent.

Present in 60%-70% of cases; non-caseating.

Lymphoid Aggregates

Absent unless deep ulceration is present.

Present, especially in non-ulcerated areas.

Crypt Architecture

Often distorted with irregular branching.

Not specifically noted.

Images

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with severe abdominal pain and distention, fever, and tachycardia. He appears ill and is in significant discomfort. Lab tests show leukocytosis and electrolyte imbalances. An X-ray of the abdomen is taken. Which of the following surgical procedures is the most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Total Abdominal Colectomy with End Ileostomy

options.label: C
options.text: Diverting Loop Ileostomy with Colonic Lavage

questions.correct_answer: B. Total Abdominal Colectomy with End Ileostomy
questions.explanation:
Imaging modalities

Abdominopelvic CT with Oral and IV Contrast
  • First-line imaging.
  • Superior for assessing disease severity, evaluating complications (e.g., abscess, perforation), and distinguishing toxic megacolon from severe acute colitis.

Serial Plain Abdominal Films
  • Frequently used modality.
  • For follow-up imaging to monitor colonic dilation.
  • CT is repeated if complications like abscesses are suspected.
 

Typical Features:

  • Greatest dilation in transverse/right colon (>6 cm, up to 15 cm)
  • Haustral pattern absent/disturbed
  • Pneumatosis
  • Multiple air-fluid levels visible
  • Deep mucosal ulcerations with air-filled crevices
  • Increased small bowel gas may predict toxic megacolon

Therapies
  • IBD-Related: Intravenous glucocorticoids (e.g., hydrocortisone 100 mg every 6-8 hours) as first-line therapy; infliximab or cyclosporine if no response within 3 days
  • C. difficile Colitis: Stop inciting antibiotics; steroids not used; metronidazole, vancomycin, or fidaxomicin for medical therapy; fecal microbial transplantation considered in some cases

Surgical Indications
  • Absolute indications: Perforation, life-threatening hemorrhage, worsening toxicity, worsening dilatation
  • IBD: Colectomy if no improvement after 24-48 hours; subtotal colectomy preferred for emergency surgery
  • C. difficile: Surgery for perforation, necrosis, or severe complications; early colectomy reduces the mortality rate

Procedure

Indications

Advantages

Disadvantages

Total Abdominal Colectomy with End Ileostomy

(Option B)

Colonic perforation, necrosis, abdominal compartment syndrome

Resolves abdominal compartment syndrome, lower mortality compared to segmental resection

More invasive, irreversible stomas in many cases

Diverting Loop Ileostomy with Colonic Lavage

(Option C)

No perforation, necrosis, or compartment syndrome

Minimally invasive, higher likelihood of stoma reversal

May leave inflamed colon, slower recovery, potential ongoing critical illness

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with severe abdominal distension and diarrhea. His vitals show a heart rate of 125 beats/min, fever of 38.9°C, and a white blood cell count of 13,800/microL. A radiograph reveals colonic dilation of 7 cm. Which of the following additional findings would not confirm the diagnosis of toxic megacolon?
questions.explanation:
Pathogenesis and Risk Factors of Toxic Megacolon

Pathogenesis

Colonic inflammation increases inducible nitric oxide synthase production, inhibiting smooth muscle tone and contributing to colonic dilatation.

Risk Factors
  • Ulcerative colitis (most common)
  • Infectious colitis: particularly Clostridium difficile infection
  • Crohn's disease
  • Hypokalemia
  • Antimotility agents
  • Opiates, Anticholinergics, Antidepressants
  • Abrupt cessation of glucocorticoids
  • Barium enemas; Colonoscopy/bowel preparation
  • Sulfasalazine and 5-ASA compounds can precipitate toxic megacolon

Diagnosis and Evaluation of Toxic Megacolon

Diagnosis Criteria

Radiographic Evidence: Colonic dilation (diameter >6 cm)

 

PLUS at least three of the following:

  • Fever >38ºC
  • Heart rate >120 beats/min
  • Neutrophilic leukocytosis >10,500/microL
  • Anemia
 

PLUS at least one of the following:

  • Dehydration
  • Altered sensorium (Option B)
  • Electrolyte disturbances (Option D)
  • Hypotension (Option C)

Differential Diagnosis
  • Congenital megacolon (Hirschsprung's disease).
  • Acquired megacolon (chronic constipation).
  • Chagas megacolon.
  • Colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome).
  • Diffuse gastrointestinal dysmotility.
  • Acute colonic obstruction from diverticulitis, volvulus, tumors.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient diagnosed with mild Crohn's disease affecting the ileocecal region presents to your clinic. The patient has mild symptoms with no significant systemic involvement. What is the most appropriate first-line drug to prescribe for this patient to induce remission in mild Crohn's disease?
questions.explanation:
Category

Mild Crohn's Disease

Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease

Induction Therapy
  • First-line: Budesonide (preferred for ileocecal disease) (Option D) or aminosalicylates (e.g., mesalamine).
  • Prednisone for those who do not respond to budesonide.
    (Option A)
  • Alternative: Enteral nutrition.
  • First-line: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone for short term) or biologics
    Anti-TNF agents (Infliximab, Adalimumab) (Option C)
  • Anti-integrin therapy (Vedolizumab)
  • Anti-interleukin therapy (Ustekinumab)
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents plus immunomodulators (Azathioprine, 6-MP) (Option B)

Maintenance Therapy
  • First-line: Continue aminosalicylates if effective.
  • Alternative: Thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP) for patients intolerant to aminosalicylates.
  • Anti-TNF monotherapy: Long-term for maintaining remission.
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents with immunomodulators (for severe cases or history of nonresponse to biologics).
  • Continue anti-integrin or anti-interleukin agents for those induced by these therapies

Monitoring
  • Regular follow-up to monitor symptoms and inflammation.
  • Ileocolonoscopy 6-12 months post-remission. Drug level monitoring and fecal calprotectin to assess mucosal healing.

Management of complex fistulising Crohn's disease

Management

Drug therapy

With Abscess:

  • Prompt surgical drainage with seton placement.
  • Initiate anti-TNF therapy post-drainage.
 

Without Abscess:

  • EUA with seton placement and anti-TNF therapy combined with antibiotics.
  • Removal of setons based on clinical response and imaging.
  • Consider switching biologics or further surgical intervention if fistula does not heal.

Initial Therapy:

  • Anti-TNF agents + antibiotics (metronidazole or ciprofloxacin).
 

Alternative/ Adjunctive:

  • Thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP), other biologics (vedolizumab, ustekinumab, upadacitinib).

questions.text: A patient with chronic ulcerative colitis who had undergone total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis has come to the department complaining of diarrhoea, abdominal pain, fever and malaise. On examination, hematochezia is noted. What is the first line of treatment here?

A 45-year-old male with a long-standing history of chronic inflammatory bowel disease presents for routine follow-up. He undergoes a colonoscopy, during which suspicious lesions are identified. A biopsy confirms the presence of malignancy. Which of the following types of cancer is more commonly associated with Crohn's disease than with ulcerative colitis?
Which of the following would be a differentiating feature of Colitis-associated colon carcinoma (CAC) from sporadic colon cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Sporadic colon cancer develops due to chronic inflammation and dysplasia

options.label: C
options.text: CAC is more common after the age of 30

options.label: D
options.text: Sporadic colon cancer is associated with young individuals

questions.correct_answer: C. CAC is more common after the age of 30
questions.explanation:
Colitis-associated colon cancer

Sporadic colon cancer
  • Age group >30 years
  • Due to prolonged colitis
  • Develops from colitis to dysplasia to carcinoma
  • Dysplasia seen here is flat dysplasia
  • Pancolonic disease: multicentric and infiltrative
  • Increased mortality (Option B)
  • Endoscopic removal or colonoscopy is done
  • Interval cancers are possible
  • Age group > 50 years
  • Most common in 8th decade (Option D)
  • Most common site is the sigmoid colon, with left-side predominance
  • Usually arises from an adenomatous polyp (Option A)

questions.text: A 58-year-old male comes to the hospital complaining of intermittent pain in the anal region and intermittent diarrhea for 6 months. On examination, he was found to have complex perianal fistulas bilaterally, with skin tags, as shown in the image. His blood investigations reveal anemia. What could be the possible diagnosis leading to this?

A patient with a history of ulcerative colitis (UC) has undergone a total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (TPA + IPAA) as part of their treatment. Which of the following is not a possible complication of the procedure?
Which of the following procedures is the definitive management of Ulcerative colitis?

options.label: B
options.text: Total Proctocolectomy with Ileal Pouch-Anal Anastomosis (TPA+IPAA)

options.label: C
options.text: Total Proctocolectomy with mucosectomy with hand-sewn IPAA

options.label: D
options.text: Total abdominal colectomy with very low Hartmann closure with end ileostomy

questions.correct_answer: B. Total Proctocolectomy with Ileal Pouch-Anal Anastomosis (TPA+IPAA)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of chronic abdominal pain, frequent bloody diarrhea, and an urgent need to defecate. Colonoscopy reveals continuous inflammation starting from the rectum and extending through the colon. Despite receiving the highest doses of medical therapy, the symptoms have worsened. Which of the following would not be considered an indication for surgery in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ulcerative colitis

Crohn’s disease:
  • Failure of maximum medical therapy (Option A)
  • Poor quality of life due to tenesmus, urgency, and low body weight.
  • Multiple bowel movements (Option B), poor nutritional status (Option D), and weak physical health.
  • Growth retardation in children or adolescents;
  • Fulminant colitis (Option C). Some of these cases may also have toxic megacolon.
  • Severe colitis leads to chronic ileus and a dilated colon, both leading to an increased risk of perforation.
  • Significant GI bleeding
  • Associated sclerosing cholangitis
  • Presence of colonic dysplasia or cancer in colonoscopic surveillance (chronic UC > 8 years)
  • Perianal disease not responding to treatment.
  • Severe extra-intestinal disease
  • Children with failure to thrive
  • Symptoms of obstruction secondary to fibrostenosing Crohn's disease
  • Perforated Crohn’s disease with associated abscess or fistula
  • Severe abdominal pain with obstruction
  • Cancer or dysplasia
  • Isolated terminal ileal disease
  • Recurrent disease
  • Incidental finding of Crohn’s during an appendectomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis has achieved clinical remission with a biologic agent. Which of the following drugs is used in the maintenance therapy for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Mild to Moderate UC

Moderate to Severe UC

Goals of Therapy

Induce and maintain clinical remission.

Achieve and maintain glucocorticoid-free remission, prevent relapse.

Initial Treatment

5-ASA compounds (e.g., mesalamine, sulfasalazine) or topical corticosteroids. (Options A & C)

5-ASA compounds, corticosteroids (Option D), or biologics (e.g., anti-TNF agents, vedolizumab).

Maintenance Therapy

5-ASA compounds; consider thiopurines for non-responders or relapsers.

Biologics (e.g., anti-TNF agents- infliximab, adalimumab (Option B); vedolizumab), thiopurines, or small molecules (e.g., JAK inhibitors).

Lab Monitoring

CBC, liver tests every 3-4 months; electrolytes and renal function annually.

Endoscopic Evaluation

Not routinely required unless symptoms persist.

Colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy every 6 months, or based on clinical need.

Inflammatory Markers

CRP and fecal calprotectin every 3-4 months if used.

Relapse Management
  • Optimize dosage, consider switching therapies if necessary.
  • Evaluate for co-existing conditions and adherence.

Specific Therapies

Thiopurines: Consider if non-responsive to 5-ASA.
  • Anti-TNF Agents
  • Vedolizumab
  • Ustekinumab
  • Mirikizumab
  • JAK Inhibitors (Tofacitinib, Upadacitinib)
  • S1P Receptor Modulators (Ozanimod, Etrasimod)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a low rectal tumor and requires bowel diversion. The surgeon is considering the type of stoma to be created. Which of the following indications best matches the need for an ileostomy rather than a colostomy?

options.label: A
options.text: To relieve bowel obstruction when resection is not feasible.

options.label: B
options.text: To protect a distal anastomosis after low anterior resection.

options.label: C
options.text: To manage inflammatory diseases with severe perianal disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Permanent fecal diversion following total colectomy

questions.correct_answer: D. Permanent fecal diversion following total colectomy
questions.explanation:
Feature

Ileostomy

Colostomy

Location

Typically located in the right iliac fossa

Typically located in the left iliac fossa

Stool Consistency

Usually results in liquid or semi-liquid stool

Produces a more formed stool

Spout

Ileostomy is usually spouted

Colostomy is usually flush

Use
  • To defunction the rest of the bowel in order to protect a distal anastomosis
  • To evacuate stool from the body if the entire colon has been removed (such as in colorectal cancer, IBD)
  • To relieve bowel obstruction
  • To protect a distal anastomosis or allow healing away from the faecal flow
  • Following resection when anastomosis is unsafe or not possible
  • To relieve obstruction when resection is not feasible
  • To reduce disease activity (e.g. Crohn’s disease)
  • To allow alternative bowel control (incontinence)

Fluid and electrolyte problems

More likely

Less likely

Appliances

Requires bags that often need to be emptied frequently due to the liquid consistency of the stool

Uses appliances that may be changed as needed, depending on the type of colostomy and stool consistency

Image

questions.text: A 39-year-old male with a 12-year history of ulcerative colitis presents with worsening symptoms despite maximum medical therapy. He experiences >10 bowel movements per day, urgency, tenesmus, and significant weight loss. Biopsies show high-grade dysplasia. The surgical team plans a total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA). What is the primary goal of the planned surgery for this patient?
Which of the following statements regarding ulcerative colitis is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Backwash ileitis, where there is secondary inflammation in the terminal ileum, is a common finding in all patients with ulcerative colitis.

options.label: B
options.text: Extraintestinal manifestations such as arthritis are more likely to occur in patients with proctitis alone.

options.label: C
options.text: 8 bloody stools per day and associated joint pain are classified as moderate ulcerative colitis.

options.label: D
options.text: Fulminant ulcerative colitis is characterized by >10 bowel movements daily, continuous bleeding, and evidence of systemic toxicity.

questions.correct_answer: D. Fulminant ulcerative colitis is characterized by >10 bowel movements daily, continuous bleeding, and evidence of systemic toxicity.
questions.explanation:
Severity

Stool Frequency

Systemic Symptoms and signs

Mild

<4 stools/day

No systemic signs of toxicity

Moderate

>4 stools/day

Fever, abdominal pain, Elevated ESR, CRP

Severe

>6 stools/day

Fever, tachycardia, anemia, systemic illness, hypoalbuminuria, Elevated ESR, CRP

Fulminant

>10 stools/day

Continuous bleeding, fever, tachycardia, abdominal tenderness & distension, “Toxic megacolon” (progressive colonic dilation, an indication for emergency surgery) in severe cases

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with a history of chronic diarrhea and rectal bleeding undergoes a barium enema for evaluation. The radiological image shows changes in the colonic mucosa. Based on the findings of the barium enema, which of the following radiological features is most indicative of Ulcerative colitis (UC)?

options.label: A
options.text: Narrowed, constricted colon with a "hose pipe" appearance

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple deep ulcers with surrounding inflammation

options.label: C
options.text: Discontinuous patches of inflammation with normal segments in between

questions.correct_answer: A. Narrowed, constricted colon with a "hose pipe" appearance

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with persistent and worsening chronic diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and abdominal pain for the past several months. An endoscopic examination reveals continuous mucosal inflammation starting at the rectum and extending proximally. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of ulcerative colitis (UC) and helps differentiate it from Crohn's disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Continuous inflammation starting from the rectum

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of granulomas in the mucosal layer

questions.correct_answer: B. Continuous inflammation starting from the rectum
questions.explanation:
Contributing factors
  • Defective mucin production: Mucosal immunological reactions
  • Autoimmune factors (Cytotoxic T cells, anticolon antibodies)
  • HLA DR2 association
  • Family history
  • Cow's milk allergy
  • Stress and lifestyle associations

Protective factors
  • Appendicectomy
  • Smoking

Sites of involvement
  • UC is confined to the large intestine.
  • Always involves the rectum; extends proximally continuously.
  • Extent of involvement:
    • Proctitis/Proctosigmoiditis (Limited to the rectum and sigmoid colon)
    • Left-Sided Colitis
    • Pancolitis (Entire colon)

Colonoscopy Findings
  • Continuous inflammation from the dentate line of the rectum and extends proximally.
  • Initially, mucosa appears erythematous, granular, or roughened; it worsens over time.
  • Ulcers are long, serpentine, covered in fibrin, with a "bear claw" appearance.
  • Significant bleeding can occur due to ulcer erosion into blood vessels.

 

Microscopic Findings
  • Inflammation limited to the mucosal layer
  • Polymorphonuclear leukocytes in lamina propria.
  • Depletion of mucin in goblet cells.
  • Crypt abscesses contain inflammatory cells within Lieberkühn crypts.
  • No granulomas, deep fissural ulcers, or transmural lymphoid aggregates.

questions.text: Which extraintestinal manifestation is most commonly associated with Crohn's disease?
questions.explanation:
1. Skin

  • Erythema nodosum
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum

2. Eyes

  • Iritis
  • Uveitis
  • Conjunctivitis

3. Blood

  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytosis
  • Phlebothrombosis
  • Arterial thrombosis

4. Joints

  • Peripheral Arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Sacroiliitis

5. Liver

  • Non-specific Hepatitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Cholesterol gallstones

6. Kidney

  • Nephrotic syndrome (Rare)

7. Urological

  • Stones (Most common type: Oxalate stones)
  • Ureteral obstruction
  • Entero-vesical fistula

8. Pancreas

  • Pancreatitis (Rare)

9. Amyloidosis (Rare)

  • Most common cutaneous manifestation of IBD - Erythema Nodosum
  • Erythema Nodosum
    1. Most responsive for Rx of bowel disease
    2. Persistence of Erythema Nodosum - Indicates inadequate control of IBD

Extraintestinal Manifestations - Affects about 30% of patients

Skin Lesions

Erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum

Joint Involvement

Arthritis, arthralgias

Eye Inflammation

Uveitis, iritis

Liver Involvement

Hepatitis, pericholangitis

Mouth Sores

Aphthous stomatitis

Other (Rare)

Amyloidosis, pancreatitis, nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of long-standing Crohn's disease presents for a follow-up examination. An abdominal X-ray with barium contrast is performed to evaluate the current state of the small bowel. Based on the barium radiographic image provided, which of the following signs is depicted below?
questions.explanation:
Radiological signs of Crohn’s disease

String sign of Kantor

Cicatrization of the ileum, which is a narrowing of the ileum caused by scarring.

Fat halo sign: Low attenuation of submucosal fat around the bowel

Rose thorn or raspberry thorn appearance: Linear transmural ulcers

Vascular jejunization of ileum: Comb sign

questions.text: A 34-year-old female with a known diagnosis of Crohn's disease presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, weight loss, and intermittent diarrhea. Imaging studies reveal significant inflammation and strictures in the gastrointestinal tract. Which part of the gastrointestinal tract is most commonly affected by Crohn's disease, leading to ulcers and strictures?
questions.explanation:
Complication

Description

Obstruction

Acute inflammation, oedema, chronic fibrotic lesions

Perforation

This leads to fistulas, localised abscesses, and rarely generalised peritonitis

Toxic Megacolon

Colonic dilation, abdominal tenderness, fever, leukocytosis

Bleeding

Chronic, indolent, possible massive bleeding with duodenal involvement

Cancer Type

Risk Factors and Characteristics

Small Intestine

Chronic mucosal inflammation, higher relative risk

M/c site in the small intestine: Ileum

Colon

Elevated risk with prolonged disease, dysplasia precursor

Small Bowel Adenocarcinoma

Aggressive, with high extracellular mucin

Extraintestinal

Squamous cell carcinoma (vulva, anal canal), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, increased with immunomodulators

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. A resection of the terminal ileum is performed, and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Continuous mucosal lesions and crypt abscesses

options.label: C
options.text: Superficial ulceration and loss of haustrations

questions.correct_answer: B. Cobblestone appearance and transmural inflammation
questions.explanation:
Feature

Crohn's Disease

Ulcerative Colitis

Gross Morphology
  • Skip lesions: Involves terminal ileum and colon
  • Cobblestone appearance: Transmural inflammation results in cobblestone mucosa
  • Continuous lesions: Affects colon in continuous manner starting from rectum
  • Presence of pseudopolyps


 

Microscopic Morphology

Transmural inflammation: Involves all layers of the bowel wall

 

Non-caseating granulomas: Characteristic finding

Mucosal inflammation: Confined to mucosa and submucosa

 

Crypt abscesses: Neutrophil infiltration into crypts

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and recent weight loss. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant, and a colonoscopy revealed patchy inflammation in the terminal ileum with skip lesions. Which of the following combinations of risk factors and etiological factors is most consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Crohn’s Disease

Ulcerative Colitis

Genetic Factors

NOD2/CARD15 gene mutation on chromosome 16 (Option A)

HLA-DR2 association (Option B)

Smoking

Increases risk

Protective effect, lowers risk (Option C)

Diet

Highly refined food, food additives, particularly preservatives

Westernized diet, red meat, milk allergy (Option D).

Less common in vegetarians.

Autoimmune Factors

Bacterial dysbiosis with aggressive T cell immune response to specific components of intestinal microbes

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes against Colonic epithelial cells and the presence of anticolon antibodies. (Option C)

Appendectomy

No clear association (Option B)

Protective

Environmental Triggers

Mycobacterium infection, high levels of sanitation in childhood

Stress, personality disorders (Option D)

Family History

Strong familial association, 10% of first-degree relatives and 50% of monozygotic twins.

Familial tendency present, less frequent

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman undergoes an emergency ileostomy following bowel obstruction. Two weeks postoperatively, she presents with increased pain and swelling around the stoma site. On examination, a bulge is noted adjacent to the stoma. The stoma itself appears healthy, with no signs of necrosis or ischemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Complications

Description

Key Characteristics

Stoma Ischemia

Lack of blood supply causing stoma discoloration and necrosis

Occurs early post-op (within days), Discolored

Stoma Prolapse (Option D)

Excessive protrusion of the stoma through the abdominal wall

Protrusion, more common in loop stomas

Stoma Retraction (Option B)

Stoma sinks below skin level; often leads to poor appliance fit and skin irritation

Concave surface, skin irritation

Parastomal Hernia (Option C)

Herniation of abdominal contents through the stoma opening

Bulging adjacent to the stoma, discomfort

Stoma Stenosis (Option A)

Narrowing of stoma, leading to obstruction

Narrowed opening, obstruction symptoms

Skin Irritation

Irritation or breakdown of skin around the stoma due to appliance use

Poor appliance fitting, leakage

Bleeding

May occur due to trauma or mucosal irritation

Trauma, irritation

Fistulation

Formation of abnormal connections between the stoma and other organs or skin

Infection

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient undergoes emergency abdominal surgery for a perforated sigmoid diverticulitis with peritonitis. The surgeon decides to create a stoma as part of the management plan. Which of the following stomas is most appropriate for diverting fecal content and allowing distal bowel healing while planning for potential future reconnection?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Common Uses

Reversibility

End Colostomy (Option A)

Single opening from the proximal bowel. Often permanent.

Used when the distal bowel is removed or left in place, e.g., Hartmann's procedure

Often permanent

Loop Ileostomy (Option B)

Loop of bowel is brought to the surface, and an incision is made

Temporary diversion, especially in emergencies, and easily reversible

Usually temporary

Double-barrel Colostomy

(Option C)

Two stomas are created: one for faecal output and one for mucus discharge

Rarely used; can be for cases requiring both resection and exteriorization, offering mucous fistula

Can be temporary

Permanent Ileostomy

(Option D)

Terminal ileum is brought to the surface after a colectomy

Used when reconnection is not planned, often after total proctocolectomy for conditions like FAP

Permanent
